file:09-2024::sec-1-short-title.text_plain: This Act may be cited as the Online Safety Act, No. 9 of 2024.
file:09-2024::sec-1-short-title.heading: Short title

legal_annotations.normalized_text: The short title of this Act is 'Online Safety Act, No. 9 of 2024'

file:09-2024::sec-2-application.text_plain: The provisions of this Act shall apply where: (a) a person commits an offence under this Act in respect of a citizen of Sri Lanka, while being present in Sri Lanka or outside Sri Lanka; (b) a loss, damage or harm is caused within or outside Sri Lanka by the commission of an offence under this Act, to the State or to a person resident in Sri Lanka; or (c) an offence under this Act, wherever committed, is committed by a person who is a citizen of Sri Lanka.
file:09-2024::sec-2-application.heading: Application of the Act

legal_annotations.normalized_text: This Act applies to: (1) offences committed by any person against Sri Lanka citizens, regardless of location; (2) harm caused to the State or residents, regardless of location; (3) offences by Sri Lanka citizens, regardless of location.
conditions: in respect of a citizen of Sri Lanka

file:09-2024::sec-3-objectives.text_plain: The objectives of this Act are: (a) to protect persons against harm caused by communication of prohibited statements, by way of an online account or through an online location; (b) to ensure protection from communication of statements in contempt of court or prejudicial to the maintenance of the authority and impartiality of the judiciary, by way of an online account or through an online location; (c) to introduce measures to detect, prevent and safeguard against the misuses of online accounts and bots to commit offences under this Act; and (d) to prevent the financing, promotion and other support of online locations which repeatedly communicate prohibited statements in Sri Lanka, by way of online account or through an online location.
file:09-2024::sec-3-objectives.heading: Objectives of the Act

legal_annotations.normalized_text: Primary objectives: (1) Protect persons from harm via prohibited online statements; (2) Protect court authority and judicial impartiality; (3) Detect and prevent misuse of accounts and bots; (4) Prevent financing of locations communicating prohibited statements.

file:09-2022::sec-5-lawful-processing.text_plain: The processing of personal data shall be lawful if a controller is in compliance with: (a) any condition specified in Schedule I; (b) any condition specified in Schedule II for special categories of personal data; (c) all conditions in Schedule III for consent-based processing; or (d) all conditions in Schedule IV for criminal investigation processing.
file:09-2022::sec-5-lawful-processing.heading: Obligation to process personal data in a lawful manner

legal_annotations.normalized_text: Controllers must ensure personal data processing is lawful and compliant with specified schedules (I, II, III, or IV depending on context).
conditions: in compliance with Schedule I, II, III, or IV

file:09-2022::sec-13-right-of-access.text_plain: Every data subject has the right to access their personal data and receive confirmation if it has been processed, upon written request. Controllers must provide information from Schedule V upon request, subject to section 17.
file:09-2022::sec-13-right-of-access.heading: Right of access to personal data

legal_annotations.normalized_text: Data subjects may request access to their personal data; controllers must comply within 21 days.

file:24-2007::sec-3-unauthorized-access.text_plain: Any person who intentionally seeks unauthorized access to a computer or information held therein, knowing or having reason to believe they lack lawful authority, commits an offence. Penalty: fine up to 100,000 rupees, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both.
file:24-2007::sec-3-unauthorized-access.heading: Securing unauthorised access to a computer an offence

legal_annotations.normalized_text: No person shall intentionally secure unauthorized access to any computer or information held therein knowing or believing they lack lawful authority.
conditions: knowing or having reason to believe no lawful authority exists

legal_annotations.normalized_text: Fine not exceeding 100,000 rupees and/or imprisonment up to 5 years.

file:24-2007::sec-6-national-security.text_plain: Any person who intentionally causes a computer to perform a function that results in danger to national security, the national economy, or public order commits an offence. Penalty: imprisonment up to 5 years.
file:24-2007::sec-6-national-security.heading: Offences committed against national security &c.

legal_annotations.normalized_text: No person shall intentionally cause a computer to perform a function that results in danger to national security, national economy, or public order.
conditions: resulting in danger to national security, national economy, or public order

file:39-2022::sec-1-short-title.text_plain: This Act may be cited as the Children and Young Persons (Amendment) Act, No. 39 of 2022. Provisions come into force on dates appointed by the Minister by Gazette Order. Different dates may apply to different provisions.
file:39-2022::sec-1-short-title.heading: Short title and date of operation

legal_annotations.normalized_text: Short title: 'Children and Young Persons (Amendment) Act, No. 39 of 2022'. Operative date: As appointed by Minister via Gazette Order.

file:39-2022::sec-2-amendment-chapter-23.text_plain: Amendments to the principal enactment (Chapter 23): (1) 'Children and Young Persons Ordinance' becomes 'Children's Ordinance'; (2) 'children and young persons' becomes 'children'; (3) 'child or young person' becomes 'child'; (4) age threshold changed from 16 to 18 years.
file:39-2022::sec-2-amendment-chapter-23.heading: Amendment of Chapter 23 and written law

legal_annotations.normalized_text: Terminology updated: Young Person status removed; age threshold elevated from 16 to 18 years; consolidation of terminology to 'child'.
